div.p: THE LAST SPEECHES OF Thomas Wentworth, Late Earle of Strafford, and Deputy of IRELAND. The one in the Tower, the other on the SCAFFOLD on Tower-Hill, May the twelfth. 1641. Together with his deportment before and at the end of his Execution.

body.head: His Speech in the Tower to the Lords, before he went to Execution.
body.p: RIght Honourable, and the re≈øt, you are now come to convey me to my death: I am willing to die, which is a thing no more than all our Predece≈ø≈øors have done, and a debt that our Po≈øterity mu≈øt in their due time di≈øcharge, which ≈øince it can be no way avoyded, it ought the le≈ø≈øe to be feared; for that which is common to all, ought not to be intollerable to any: It is the Law of Nature, the tribute of the fle≈øh, remedy from all worldly cares and troubles; and to the truly penitent, a perfect path to ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe. And there is but one death, though ≈øeverall wayes unto it: mine is not naturall, but enforced by the Law and Iu≈øtice: It hath been ≈øaid that the Lawes vex onely the meaner ≈øort of people, but the mighty are able to defend them: it is not ≈øo with me, for to the Law I ≈øubmit my ≈øelfe, and confe≈ø≈øe that I receive nothing but Iu≈øtice: for he that politikly intendeth good to a Common-weale, may be called a ju≈øt man, but he that practi≈øeth either for his owne profit, or any other ≈øini≈øter ends, may be well tearmed a delinquent per≈øon; neither is delay in puni≈øhment any priviledge for pardon. And moreover, I ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe with Cicero, That the death of the bad is the ≈øafety of the good that be alive.

Let no man tru≈øt either in the favour of his Prince, the friend≈øhip and con≈øanguinity of his Peeres, much le≈ø≈øe in his owne wi≈øedome and knowledge, of which I ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øe I have been too confident. Kings, as they are men before God, ≈øo they are Gods before men, and I may ≈øay with a great man once in this Kingdome, Had I ≈øtrived to obey my God as faithfully, as I ≈øought to honour my King diligently, I had ≈øtood, and not fallen. Mo≈øt happy and fortunate is that Prince, who is as much for his ju≈øtice feared, as for his goodne≈ø≈øe beloved: For the greater that Princes are in power above other, the more they ought in vertue to excell other; and ≈øuch is the Royall Soveraigne whom I late ≈øerved.

For my Peeres, the corre≈øpondence that I had with them during my pro≈øperity, was to me very delightfull and plea≈øing, and here they have commi≈øerated my ruine, I have plentifully found, who (for the mo≈øt generous of them) I may boldly ≈øay, though they have dete≈øted the fact, yet they have pittied the per≈øon delinquent; the fir≈øt in their loyalty, the la≈øt in their Charity: ingenuou≈øly confe≈ø≈øing, that never any ≈øubject,
or Peere of my rank, had ever that helpe of Coun≈øell, that benefit of time, or a more free and legall tryall than I have had: in the like whereof, none of my predece≈ø≈øors hath had ≈øo much favour from his Prince, ≈øo much ≈øufferance from the people; in which I comprehend the under≈øtanding Commons, not the many headed Mon≈øter, Multitude: But I have offended, am ≈øentenced, and mu≈øt now ≈øuffer.

And for my too much confidence in my ≈øuppo≈øed wi≈ødom & knowledge, therein have bin the mo≈øt deceived: for he is wi≈øe to him≈øelf, that knowes by others faults to correct his owne offences: to be truely wi≈øe is to be Secretaries to our ≈øelves; for it is meere folly to reveale our intimate thoughts to ≈øtrangers: wi≈ødom is the mo≈øt precious Gem with which the mind can be adorned, and learning the mo≈øt famous thing for which a man ought to be e≈øteemed, and true wi≈ødome teacheth us to doe well, as to ≈øpeake well: in the fir≈øt I have failed, for the wi≈ødome of man is fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe with God.

For knowledge, it is a thing indifferent both to good and evill, but the be≈øt knowledge is for a man to know him≈øelfe; hee that doth ≈øo ≈øhall e≈øteeme of him≈øelfe but little, for he con≈øidereth from whence hee came, and whereto he mu≈øt goe, he regardeth not the vaine plea≈øures of this life, he exalteth God, and ≈øtrives to live in his feare; but hee that knoweth not him≈øelfe, is wilfull in his own wayes, unprofitable in his life, unfortunate in his death, and ≈øo am I. But the rea≈øon why I ≈øought to attaine unto it, was this: I have read that he that knoweth not that which he ought to know, is a bruit bea≈øt among men; hee that knoweth more than he ought to know, is a man among≈øt bea≈øts: but hee that knoweth all that may be known, is a God among≈øt men. To this I much a≈øpired, in this I much failed; Vanity of vanities, all is but vanity.

I have heard the people clamour and cry out, ≈øaying, That through my occa≈øion the times are bad, I wi≈øh that when I am dead they may prove better: mo≈øt true it is, that there is at this time a great ≈øtorme impending (God in his mercy avert it.) And ≈øince it is my particular lot, like Ionah, to be ca≈øt into the ≈øea, I ≈øhall thinke my life well ≈øpent, to appea≈øe Gods wrath, and ≈øatisfie the peoples malice.

O what is eloquence more than ayre? fa≈øhioned with an articulate and di≈øtinct ≈øound, when it is a ≈øpeciall vertue to ≈øpeake little and well, and ≈øilence is oft the be≈øt Oratory; for fools in their dumbne≈ø≈øe may be accounted wi≈øe: It hath power to make a good matter ≈øeeme bad, and a bad cau≈øe appeare good: but mine was to me unprofitable, and like the Cypre≈ø≈øe trees, which are great and tall, but altogether without fruit.

What is honour? but the fir≈øt ≈øtep to di≈øquietne≈ø≈øe, and power is ≈øtill
waited on by envy, neither hath it any priviledge again≈øt infamy. It is held to be the chiefe part of honour, for a man to joyne to his office and calling; curte≈øie and affability, commi≈øeration and pitty: for thereby he draweth to him with a kind of compul≈øion, the hearts of the multitude. But that was the lea≈øt part of my ≈øtudy, which now makes me call to minde, that the greater the per≈øons are in authority, the ≈øooner they are catcht in any delinquency, and their ≈ømalle≈øt crimes are thought to be Capitall, the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øpot ≈øeems great in the fine≈øt linen, and the lea≈øt flaw is ≈øoone≈øt found in the riche≈øt Diamond. But high and Noble ≈øpirits finding them≈øelves wounded, grieve not ≈øo much at their owne paine and perplexity, as at the deri≈øion and ≈øcoffes of their enemy: but for mine own part, though I might have many in my life, I hope to find none in my death.

Among≈øt other things which pollute and contaminate the minds of great ≈øpirits, there is none more hainous then Ambition, which is ≈øeldome unacompanied with Avarice: Such to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe their ends, care not to violate the Lawes of Religion, and Rea≈øon, and to breake the bonds of Mode≈øty and Equity, with the neare≈øt tyes of Con≈øanguinity, and Amity; of which as I have beene guilty, ≈øo I crave at Gods hands forgivene≈ø≈øe. It is a Maxime in Philo≈øophy, that ambitious men can be never good Coun≈øellors to Princes; the de≈øire of having more is common to great Lords, and a de≈øire of Rule a great cau≈øe of their Ruine.

My Lords, I am now the hopele≈ø≈øe Pre≈øident, may I be to you all an happy example: For Ambition devoureth gold, and drinketh blood, and climbeth ≈øo high by other mens heads, that at the length in the fall, it breaketh its owne neck: therefore it is better to live in humble content, than in high care and trouble: For more precious is want with hone≈øty, than wealth with infamy: For what are we but meere Vapours, which in a ≈øerene Element a≈øcend high, and upon an in≈øtant, like Smoake vani≈øh into nothing: or like ≈øhips without Pilots, to≈øt up and downe upon the Seas by contrary winds and tempe≈øts. But the good husbandman thinkes better of tho≈øe eares of Corne, which bow down, and grow crooked, than tho≈øe which are ≈øtraight and upright, becau≈øe he is a≈ø≈øured to finde more ≈øtore of Grain in the one than in the other. This all men know, yet of this, how few make u≈øe: The defect whereof mu≈øt be now my pain: may my ≈øuffering prove to others profit.

For what hath now the favour of my Prince, the familiarity with my Peeres, the volubility of a tongue, the ≈øtrength of my memory, my learning, or knowledge, my honours, or Offices, my power, and potency, my riches, and trea≈øure, (all the≈øe the ≈øpeciall gifts, both of Nature, and Fortune) what have all the≈øe profited me? Ble≈ø≈øings I acknowledge,
though by God be≈øtowed upon man, yet not all of them together upon many: yet by the divine Providence, the mo≈øt of them met in me: of which had I made happy u≈øe, I might ≈øtill have flouri≈øht, who now am forced immaturely to fall.

I now could wi≈øh, (but that utinam is too late) that God with his outward goodne≈ø≈øe towards me had ≈øo commixed his inward grace, that I had chu≈øed the medium path, neither inclining to the right hand, nor deviating to the left; but like Icarus with my waxen wings, fearing by too low a flight to moi≈øten them with the Waves: I ≈øoared too high, and too neare the Sun, by which they being melted, I aiming at the highe≈øt, am precipitated to the lowe≈øt, and am made a wretched prey to the Waters: But I who before built my hou≈øe upon the ≈øand, have now ≈øetled my hopes upon the Rock my Saviour: by who≈øe only merits my ≈øole tru≈øt is, that what≈øoever becomes of my body, yet in this bo≈øome my ≈øoule may be ≈øanctuaried.

Nimrod would have built a Tower to reach up to heaven, and called it Babel; but God turned it to the confu≈øion of Languages, and di≈ø≈øipation of the people. Pharaoh kept the children of I≈ørael in Bondage and after having freed them, in his great pride would have made them his prey; but God gave them a dry and miraculous pa≈ø≈øage, and Pharaoh and his hoa≈øt a watry Sepulchre. Bel≈øhazzer fea≈øted his Princes and Pro≈øtitutes, who drunke healths in the Ve≈ø≈øels taken from the Temple, but the hand of God writ upon the wall, Mene, Tekel, Phoras, and that night before morning, was both his kingdome and life taken from him: Thus God lets men go on a great while in their own devices, but in the end it proves their own ruine and de≈øtruction, never ≈øuffering them to effect their de≈øired purpo≈øes: therefore let none pre≈øume upon his power, glory in his greatne≈ø≈øe, or be too confident in his riches: The≈øe things were written for our In≈øtruction, of which the living may make u≈øe, the dying cannot; but wit and unfruitfull wi≈ødome are the next neighbours to folly.

There can be no greater vanity in the world, than to e≈øteeme the world, which regardeth no man; and to make ≈ølight account of God who greatly re≈øpecteth all men; and there can be no greater folly in man, than by much Travell to encrea≈øe his goods, and pamper his body, and in the interim with vain delights and plea≈øures, to lo≈øe his ≈øoul. It is a great folly in any man to attempt a bad beginning, in hope of good ending; and to make that proper to one, which was before common to all, is meere indi≈øcretion, and the beginning of di≈øcord, which I po≈øitively wi≈øh may end in this my puni≈øhment.

O how ≈ømall a proportion of earth will containe my body, when
my high minde could not be confined within the ≈øpacious compa≈ø≈øe of two Kingdomes? But my houre draweth on, and I conclude with the P≈øalmi≈øt, not aiming at any one man in particular, but ≈øpeaking for all in generall: How long will you Iudges be corrupted? how long will yee cea≈øe to give true Iudgement? &c. Ble≈ø≈øed is the man that doth not walke in the Councell of the wicked, nor ≈øtand in the way of ≈øinners, nor ≈øit in the ≈øeat of the ≈øcornfull, therefore they ≈øhall not ≈øtand in the Iudgement, nor ≈øinners in the a≈ø≈øembly of the righteous, &c.

div.p: About the houre of twelve a clock the afore≈øaid Lord of Strafford was conveyed to the Scaffold on Tower hill, where was a Court of Guard made by the ≈øeverall Companies of the Souldiers of the City of London, and the Hamlets of the Tower on each ≈øide as he pa≈ø≈øed to the Scaffold: before marched the Mar≈øhals men to make way, then the Sheriffes of Londons Officers with their Halberds; after them the Kings Guard, or Warders of the Tower; Next came one of his Gentlemen, bare headed, in mourning habit, the Lord Strafford following him clad in black Cloth, with divers others in the ≈øame habit, which were his attendants; then the Lord Bi≈øhop of Armagh, and other good Divines; with the Sheriffes of London, and divers honourable per≈øonages.

When he came to the Scaffold, he there ≈øhewed him≈øelfe on each ≈øide in full view to all people, and made this ≈øhort ≈øpeech, with as much alacrity of ≈øpirit, as a mortall man could expre≈ø≈øe, viz.

body.head: The Earle of Straffords fir≈øt Speech on the Scaffold.
body.p:
MY Lord Primate of Ireland (and my Lords, and the re≈øt of the≈øe Gentlemen) it is a very great comfort to me, to have your Lord≈øhip by mee this day, in regard I have been knowne to you a long time: I ≈øhould be very glad to obtain ≈øo much ≈øilence, as to be heard a few words, but I doubt I ≈øhall not; my Lord I come hither by the good will and plea≈øure of Almighty God, to pay that la≈øt debt I owe to ≈øin, which is death, and by the ble≈ø≈øing of that God to ri≈øe again through the merits of Chri≈øt Je≈øus to eternall glory; I wi≈øh I had been private, that I might have been heard; My Lord, if I might bee ≈øo much
beholding to you, that I might u≈øe a few words, I ≈øhould take it for a very great curte≈øie; My Lord, I come hither to ≈øubmit to that judgement which hath pa≈øt again≈øt me, I doe it with a very quiet and contented minde, I doe freely forgive all the world, a forgivene≈ø≈øe that is not ≈øpoken from teeth outward (as they ≈øay) but from the heart; I ≈øpeake it in the pre≈øence of Almighty God, before whom I ≈øtand, that there is not ≈øo much as a di≈øplea≈øing thought in mee ari≈øing to any creature; I thanke God I may ≈øay truly, and my Con≈øcience beares me witne≈ø≈øe, that in all my ≈øervices ≈øince I have had the honour to ≈øerve his Maje≈øty in any employment, I never had any thing in my heart, but the joynt and individuall pro≈øperity of King and People; if it have been my hap to be mi≈øcon≈øtrued, it is the common portion of us all while we are in this life, the righteous judgement is hereafter, here we are ≈øubject to error, and apt to be misjudged one of another; there is one thing I de≈øire to cleere my ≈øelfe of, and I am very confident, I ≈øpeake it with ≈øo much clearene≈ø≈øe, that I hope I ≈øhall have your Chri≈øtian charity in the beliefe of it; I did alwaies ever thinke the Parliaments of England, were the happie≈øt Con≈øtitutions that any Kingdome, or any Nation lived under, and under God the meanes of making King and People happy, ≈øo far have I been from being again≈øt Parliaments; for my death, I here acquit all the world, and pray God heartily to forgive them; and in particular, my Lord Primate, I am very glad that his Maje≈øty is plea≈øed to conceive me not meriting ≈øo ≈øevere, and heavy a puni≈øhment as the utmo≈øt execution of this ≈øentence; I am very glad, and infinitely rejoyce in this mercy of his, and be≈øeech God to turne it to him, that he may finde mercy when he hath mo≈øt need of it; I wi≈øh this Kingdome all the pro≈øperity and happine≈ø≈øe in the world: I did it living, and now dying it is my wi≈øh, I doe now profe≈ø≈øe it from my heart, and doe mo≈øt humbly recommend it unto every man here, and wi≈øh every man to
lay his hand upon his heart, and con≈øider ≈øeriou≈øly whether the beginning of the happine≈ø≈øe of a People ≈øhould bee written in letters of Blood, I feare you are in a wrong way, and I de≈øire Almighty God that no one drop of my Blood may ri≈øe up in judgement again≈øt you.

(My Lord,) I profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe a true and obedient Son to the Church of England, to that Church wherein I was borne, and wherein I was bred; pro≈øperity and happine≈ø≈øe, be ever to it: and whereas it hath been ≈øaid that I have enclin'd to Popery, if it be an Objection worth an≈øwering, let me ≈øay truly, that from the time ≈øince I was one and twenty yeares of age, till this houre, now going upon 49. I never had thought in my heart, to doubt of the truth of my Religion in England: and never any had the boldne≈ø≈øe to ≈øugge≈øt to me the contrary, to the be≈øt of my remembrance; and ≈øo being reconciled to the mercies of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus my Saviour, into who≈øe bo≈øome I hope ≈øhortly to be gather'd to tho≈øe eternall happine≈ø≈øes that ≈øhall never have end. I de≈øire heartily the forgivene≈ø≈øe of every man, both for any ra≈øh or unadvi≈øed word, or deed, and de≈øire your Prayers: And ≈øo my Lords farewell, farewell all the things of this world, LORD ≈øtrengthen my faith, give me confidence and a≈ø≈øurance in the merits of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. I de≈øire you that you would be ≈øilent and joyne in Prayers with me; and I tru≈øt in GOD that we ≈øhall all meet and live eternally in Heaven, there to receive the accompli≈øhment of all happine≈ø≈øe, where every teare ≈øhall be wiped from our eyes, and every ≈øad thought from our hearts: And ≈øo God ble≈ø≈øe this Kingdome, and Ie≈øus have mercy upon my Soule.

div.p: THen turning him≈øelfe about, he ≈øaluted all the Noblemen, and tooke a ≈øolemne leave of all con≈øiderable per≈øons on the Scaffold, giving them his hand.

And after that he ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I would ≈øay my prayers, and I intreat you all to pray with me, and for me; then his Chaplaine laid the booke of Common prayer upon the
Chaire before him as he kneeled down, on which he prayed almo≈øt a quarter of an houre, then he prayed as long or longer without a booke, and ended with the Lords prayer; then ≈øtanding up he ≈øpies his brother Sir George Wentworth, and calls him to him, and ≈øaith, brother wee mu≈øt part, remember me to my ≈øi≈øter, and to my wife, and carry my ble≈ø≈øing to my elde≈øt Son, and charge him from mee, that he feare God and continue an obedient Sonne of the Church of England, and that he ≈øhould approve him≈øelfe a faithfull ≈øubject to the King, and tell him that he ≈øhould not have any private grudge or revenge towards any concerning me, and bid him beware that he meddle not with Church livings, for that will prove a moath and canker to him in his e≈øtate, and wi≈øh him to content him≈øelfe to be a ≈øervant to his Countrey, as a Ju≈øtice of peace in his County, and not aiming at higher preferments; carry my ble≈ø≈øing al≈øo to my daughters, Anne and Arrabella, charge them to feare and ≈øerve God‚ñ™ and he will ble≈ø≈øe them, not forgetting my little Infant that yet knowes neither good nor evill, and cannot ≈øpeake for it ≈øelfe, God ≈øpeake for it and ble≈ø≈øe it; then ≈øaid he, now I have nigh done, one ≈øtroke will make my wife husbandle≈ø≈øe, my deare children fatherle≈ø≈øe, and my poore ≈øervants ma≈øterle≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeperate mee from my deare brother and all my friends, but let God be to you and them, all in all.

After that, going to take off his dublet, and to make him≈øelfe unready, he ≈øaid, I thanke God I am no more afraid of death, nor daunted with any di≈øcouragements ri≈øing from any feares, but doe as chearefully put off my dublet at this time, as ever I did when I went to bed. Then he put off his dublet, and wound up his haire with his hands, and put on a white Cap.
